posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
Hiya all! Is there an easy way for robot code to tell if it’s at a competition? Possibly something that can tell if the radio has been reconfigured for a comp instead of at-home use. An example use case: Data Logging is used when testing autos in the shop. When going to competition though, Data Logging should always occur. Thus, if at comp → data log.

I know plenty of semi-autonomous ways to accomplish this, and the above might not be the right solution for us, but I am still curious. Thanks!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: You could use DriverStation::isFMSAttached .  Wont tell you generally if you’re at the event, but should tell you if youre connected to an official field (so will “false positive” for offseasons as well)

The method listed in the first comment will indeed work if you are on the field at the start of autonomous.  You get no guarantees that the FMS will be attached before that moment (at robotInit).

I do have to ask here: why not data log always?  The logs are tiny and have no meaningful impact on robot code performance.  They also give you more insight when something strange happens.

If space is an issue, to onto Amazon and pick up a tiny USB drive, they’re like $10 a piece, which is a small price to pay imo for possibly saving you hours of development time over a season.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
wanderingcarrot:

I do have to ask here: why not data log always?

Data logging was just a random example I came up with. Not necessarily an end goal.

Regardless:

wanderingcarrot:

a small price to pay imo for possibly saving you hours of development time over a season.

I do love spending small amounts of money to save large amounts of time!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.cooked: We build two robots and needed a way to distinguish between them for swerve offsets and the like, so we made a thing that plugs in to a DIO port and simply shorts it. We only plugged this in to our practice robot. What you can do and we were thinking of doing is having another switch for a debugging mode, currently we just have a boolean flag in our code for debug modes.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: DataLogManager should already be doing that .  Is that functionality not working for you?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
TIL - I’m not sure actually. I can go back to see if I have DS logs later this week indicating a double rename.

The actual source of the function is carryover from when we had our own CSV logger last year - I just saw the rename function and ported over the logic to execute a rename at the start of autonomous.

posts.name: Tinnittin
posts.cooked: You can put a file on the roborio with those presets or a simple text with with some ID in it. When the robot starts up, have it read those values or the ID and use the appropriate values for that robot. Though you do have to be careful if you reflash the rio you’ll lose those files.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Tinnittin:

file on the roborio with those presets or a simple text with with some ID in it

That file is provided for us by NI with the text from the comment field of the roboRIO dashboard. The restrictions you mentioned about it not lasting through a re-flash apply. Here’s our example of accessing the comment file /etc/machine-info different roboRIOs - different constants EDIT: this is a much better way to access the roboRIO COMMENTS:

Peter_Johnson:

You can also use the “Comments” field on the Rio’s web dashboard to set an arbitrary string. This can be read using RobotController.getComments().
The solution my team was that will survive a reflash is using the serial number of the Rio.  There’s a method for getting it now in RobotController.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: You can also use the “Comments” field on the Rio’s web dashboard to set an arbitrary string.  This can be read using RobotController.getComments().

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
Peter_Johnson:

You can also use the “Comments” field on the Rio’s web dashboard to set an arbitrary string. This can be read using RobotController.getComments().

Right, but that wouldn’t survive a reflash, no?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
neither would local file suggested by others.

Personally - I’m mostly a fan of the jumper option. Makes it trivial to swap RIO’s between the bots. Which, while not a common operation, is something you don’t want to have go wrong at the last minute.
